label.text: Black Soldier Fly
The black soldier fly (Hermetia illucens) is a common and fast-growing insect species that is native to South America.
In recent times the black soldier fly has spread to other continents, including North America, Europe, Africa and Asia.
The diagram shows the life cycle of the black soldier fly.
A female adult can lay up to 500 eggs at one time.
adult fly
eggs
larva
pupa
Black soldier flies are sometimes considered beneficial because they prey on other insects, such as the housefly (Musca domestica).
Explain what will happen to a population of houseflies as a population of black soldier flies increases.
Black soldier fly larvae are rich in protein and can be used as a food source for other animals, including chickens.
Farmers breed the flies in compost systems. When the larvae are harvested, some larvae are deliberately left in the compost system.
Why are some larvae left in the compost system?
The larval stage of the black soldier fly lasts for two weeks.
The larvae feed on decaying organic material, such as manure and rotting vegetation.
The larvae shed their outer body covering (exoskeleton) several times during this stage.
Why do the larvae shed their outer body covering?
They feed on larger pieces of food as they grow.
They grow rapidly and outgrow their body covering.
They are very active and their body covering becomes damaged.
They grow too large for their backbone to support them.
